MMG141.name: Introductory Human Genetics
MMG141.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MMG141.description: Inheritance of human traits. Impact of genetic technology on society. Ethical and legal issues. Risks and benefits of genetic technology.
MMG141.restrictions: Not open to students in the Biochemistry and Molecular Biology major or in the Biological Science Major or in the Biomedical Laboratory Science Major or in the Clinical Laboratory Sciences Major or in the Environmental Biology/Microbiology Major or in the Environmental Biology/Plant Biology Major or in the Environmental Biology/Zoology Major or in the Genomics and Molecular Genetics Major or in the Human Biology Major or in the Microbiology Major or in the Neuroscience Major or in the Physiology Major or in the Plant Biology Major or in the Zoology Major and not open to students in the Lyman Briggs Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Biological Science-Interdepartmental Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Biomedical Laboratory Science Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Environmental Biology/Plant Biology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Environmental/Biology/Microbiology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Environmental Biology/Zoology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Genomics and Molecular Genetics Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Human Biology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Major or in the Lyman Briggs Microbiology Coordinate Major.

MMG161.name: Cell and Molecular Biology
MMG161.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MMG161.description: Macromolecular synthesis. Energy metabolism. Molecular aspects of development. Molecular genetics.
MMG161.prerequisite: (CEM 141 or concurrently) or (CEM 151 or concurrently) or (LB 171 or concurrently) or (CEM 181H or concurrently)

MMG171.name: Cell and Molecular Biology Laboratory
MMG171.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MMG171.description: Principles and applications of common techniques used in cell and molecular biology.

MMG181H.name: Honors Cell and Molecular Biology
MMG181H.description: Physicochemical and molecular organization of cells as the unifying framework for genetics, evolution, and the social relevance of biology.
MMG181H.prerequisite: (CEM 141 or concurrently) or (CEM 151 or concurrently) or (CEM 181H or concurrently) or (LB 171 or concurrently)

MMG191H.name: Honors Cell and Molecular Biology Laboratory
MMG191H.description: Basic techniques of cellular and molecular biology including experimental design and hypothesis formulation; biochemistry, molecular biology and genetics.

MMG201.name: Fundamentals of Microbiology
MMG201.description: Microbial structure, function, growth, control, and diversity. Role of microbes in health, industry, and the environment.

MMG301.name: Introductory Microbiology
MMG301.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MMG301.description: Fundamentals of microbiology, including microbial structure and function, nutrition and growth, death and control. Importance and applications of major microbial groups.
MMG301.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and ((CEM 251 or concurrently) or (CEM 351 or concurrently) or (CEM 143 or concurrently))

MMG302.name: Introductory Laboratory for General and Allied Health Microbiology
MMG302.description: Methodology of microbiology. Microscopy, staining, aseptic technique, media, quantification, diagnostics, and laboratory safety.

MMG365.name: Medical Microbiology
MMG365.description: Laboratory diagnosis, disease and epidemiology of the most common bacterial, viral, fungal and parasitic pathogens and concepts in infectious disease control, prevention and treatment.

MMG365L.name: Medical Microbiology Laboratory
MMG365L.description: Practical experience in safely and accurately performing standard clinical microbiology tests to diagnose disease-causing microbes.

MMG400.name: Introduction to Bioinformatics
MMG400.description: Managing and analyzing biological data with bioinformatic tools, basic programming, and statistics.
MMG400.prerequisite: (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421) and (PLB 203 or MMG 201 or BMB 200 or BS 161)

MMG404.name: Human Genetics
MMG404.description: Inheritance of human traits. Medical, molecular, physiological and forensic applications. Biochemical, clinical, and molecular genetics of human disease. Prenatal, pre-symptomatic, and clinical diagnosis. Ethical, legal and social considerations.

MMG408.name: Advanced Microbiology Laboratory (W)
MMG408.description: Microbiological techniques and procedures to study physiology and genetics of bacteria and bacteriophages. Collection and critical assessment of quantitative data and written communication of results.
MMG408.prerequisite: (MMG 302 and (MMG 431 or concurrently)) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
MMG408.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics or in the Genetics Major or in the Environmental Biology/Microbiology Major or in the Microbiology Major.

MMG409.name: Eukaryotic Cell Biology
MMG409.description: Structure and function of nucleated cells. Emphasis on the molecular mechanisms that underlie cell processes.
MMG409.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and ((BMB 401 or concurrently) or (BMB 462 or concurrently))

MMG410.name: Bioinformatics and Computational Biology
MMG410.description: Computational approaches in modern biology with a focus on applications in genomics, systems biology, evolution, and structural biology.
MMG410.prerequisite: {(CMSE 201 and LB 144 and LB 145) or (CMSE 201 and BS 161 and BS 162) or (CMSE 201 and BS 181H and BS 182H)} and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421 or STT 351 or ECE 280)

MMG411.name: Computational Medicine
MMG411.description: Computational approaches in biology with a focus on medicine.
MMG411.prerequisite: (CMSE 201 and LB 144 and LB 145) or (CMSE 201 and BS 161 and BS 162) or (CMSE 201 and BS 181H and BS 182H)

MMG413.name: Virology
MMG413.description: Viruses and modern molecular biology. Viral replication and gene expression of the major classes of viruses. Virus-cell interactions and viral diseases.

MMG421.name: Prokaryotic Cell Physiology
MMG421.description: Prokaryotic cell structure and function. Growth and replication. Macromolecular synthesis and control.
MMG421.prerequisite: (MMG 301 and (BMB 461 or concurrently)) or (MMG 301 and (BMB 401 or concurrently))

MMG425.name: Microbial Ecology
MMG425.description: Microbial population and community interactions. Microbial activities in natural systems, including associations with plants or animals.

MMG431.name: Microbial Genetics
MMG431.description: Genetics of bacteria, their viruses, plasmids, and transposons. Emphasis on genetic principles.

MMG433.name: Microbial Genomics
MMG433.description: Structure of microbial genomes and implications for growth and evolution of bacteria and fungi. Computer analysis of genome sequence databases. Applications to gene expression and phylogenetic analysis.

MMG434.name: Laboratory in Genomics and Molecular Genetics (W)
MMG434.description: Genomics and molecular genetic techniques using microbes. Collection and critical assessment of quantitative data and written communication of results.
MMG434.prerequisite: (MMG 301 and (MMG 433 or concurrently)) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
MMG434.restrictions: Open to students in the Genomics and Molecular Genetics Major or in the Lyman Briggs Genomics and Molecular Genetics Coordinate Major.

MMG435.name: Geomicrobiology
MMG435.description: Geological and microbiological perspectives on microbial activities in diverse environmental settings, including geological change mediated by microorganisms, microbial evolution driven by geologically diverse habitats.
MMG435.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Natural Science or in the Lyman Briggs College.

MMG440.name: Food Microbiology
MMG440.description: Major groups of microorganisms of importance to the food industry. Ecological, physiological, and public health aspects.
MMG440.prerequisite: (MMG 201 or MMG 301) and completion of Tier I writing requirement.

MMG441.name: Food Microbiology Laboratory
MMG441.description: Methods for studying major groups of microorganisms important to the food industry. Isolation, enumeration, characterization, identification, and use of microorganisms.
MMG441.prerequisite: (FSC 440 or concurrently) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MMG445.name: Microbial Biotechnology (W)
MMG445.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
MMG445.description: Applications of microbial products and processes in areas such as biopharmaceuticals, bioremediation, biocatalysis and other green chemistries.
MMG445.prerequisite: (MMG 301 or BMB 461 or BMB 401) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

MMG451.name: Immunology
MMG451.description: Structure and function of molecules involved in immune responses. Quantification of immune responses and cellular participants. Immunologic abnormalities. Immunotherapy. Experimental approaches to dissection of immune functions.
MMG451.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and ((BMB 401 or concurrently) or (BMB 461 or concurrently))

MMG461.name: Molecular Pathogenesis
MMG461.description: Molecular basis of microbial virulence. Nature of determinants and their role in overcoming host defense mechanisms.

MMG465.name: Advanced Medical Microbiology
MMG465.description: Advanced laboratory diagnosis, epidemiology, and prevention of infectious diseases using an anatomical system specimen approach to study a comprehensive set of human pathogens and microbiota.

MMG465L.name: Advanced Medical Microbiology Laboratory
MMG465L.description: Practical experience in safely and accurately performing standard clinical microbiology tests to process clinical specimens, identify pathogens and perform and interpret susceptibility testing.

MMG490.name: Special Problems in Microbiology
MMG490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MMG490.description: Library research or tutorial instruction in advanced laboratory techniques.

MMG491.name: Current Topics in Microbiology and Molecular Genetics
MMG491.description: Capstone experience for microbiology majors. Presentation and discussion of journal articles. Writing of position papers. Topics such as microbial physiology, ecology, genetics, molecular biology, virology, immunology, or pathogenesis.
MMG491.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Lyman Briggs College or in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics or in the Lyman Briggs Genomics and Molecular Genetics Coordinate Major.

MMG492.name: Undergraduate Research Seminar
MMG492.description: Presentation and group discussion of undergraduate research results.
MMG492.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics or in the Lyman Briggs Genomics and Molecular Genetics Coordinate Major.

MMG499.name: Undergraduate Research
MMG499.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MMG499.description: Participation in a laboratory research project.
MMG499.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics or in the Lyman Briggs Environmental/Biology/Microbiology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Genomics and Molecular Genetics Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Microbiology Coordinate Major.

MMG499H.name: Honors Research
MMG499H.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MMG499H.description: Research project with thesis and oral report. A portion of Microbiology or Genomics and Molecular Genetics capstone experience.
MMG499H.restrictions: Open to students in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics or in the Lyman Briggs Environmental/Biology/Microbiology Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Genomics and Molecular Genetics Coordinate Major or in the Lyman Briggs Microbiology Coordinate Major.

MMG522.name: Medical Microbiology and Immunology
MMG522.description: Basic principles of microbiology (bacteriology, virology, mycology and parasitology) and immunology and their relation to disease in humans.
MMG522.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine or in the College of Human Medicine.

MMG531.name: Medical Immunology
MMG531.description: Basic principles of immunology. Overview of concepts and terminology in relation to human disease defenses.
MMG531.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

MMG532.name: Medical Microbiology
MMG532.description: Basic principles of microbiology including bacteriology, virology, mycology, and parasitology and their relationship to disease in humans.
MMG532.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

MMG539.name: Principles of Cell Biology and Pathophysiology
MMG539.description: Modern concepts of human cell biology as a basis for understanding integration of structure (histology) and function (physiology) in health and disease (pathology). Introduction to adaptive growth response, cell injury, inflammation, hemodynamic disorders, and tissue repair.
MMG539.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Osteopathic Medicine.

MMG559.name: Veterinary Microbiology and Immunology
MMG559.description: Medically important properties of veterinary pathogens. Principles of positive and negative host response.
MMG559.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

MMG563.name: Veterinary Pathogenic Microbiology: Bacteria and Fungi
MMG563.description: Etiology, pathogenesis, transmission, pathogenicity, host response, therapy, and control of bacterial and fungal diseases of animals.
MMG563.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

MMG565.name: Veterinary Pathogenic Microbiology: Viruses
MMG565.description: Etiology, pathogenesis, pathogenicity, transmission, diagnosis, host response, therapy, and control of selected viral diseases of animals.
MMG565.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

MMG571.name: Veterinary Pathogenic Microbiology: Parasites
MMG571.description: Etiology, pathogenesis, transmission, pathogenicity, diagnosis, host response, therapy, and control of selected parasitic diseases of animals.
MMG571.restrictions: Open to graduate-professional students in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

MMG660.name: Veterinary Clinical Bacteriology Clerkship
MMG660.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

MMG662.name: Clinical Veterinary Virology Clerkship
MMG662.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

MMG664.name: Veterinary Clinical Parasitology Clerkship
MMG664.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

MMG690.name: Veterinary Microbiology Clerkship
MMG690.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MMG690.description: Laboratory-based investigation of microbiological problems pertinent to veterinary medicine.

MMG801.name: Integrative Microbial Biology
MMG801.description: Structural, metabolic, phylogenetic, and genomic diversity of microbes and microbial communities. Microbial ecology, evolution, and behavior. Regulation of gene expression. Microbial interactions with other microbes, animals, or plants
MMG801.exclude: MMG 821 or MMG 829 or MMG 841 or MMG 827

MMG803.name: Topics in Integrative Microbial Biology
MMG803.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MMG803.description: In-depth study of a particular topic from integrative microbial biology.

MMG810.name: Theories and Practices in Bioinformatics
MMG810.description: Theories and algorithms behind bioinformatics tools. Basic tool development by writing scripts in the Python programming language for data analysis.

MMG813.name: Molecular Virology
MMG813.description: Molecular nature and biochemistry of replication of animal viruses. Current advances, research concepts, and the role of viruses in molecular biology research.
MMG813.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Colleges of Human Medicine, Osteopathic Medicine, Veterinary Medicine, Natural Science, and Agriculture and Natural Resources.

MMG825.name: Cell Structure and Function
MMG825.description: Molecular basis of structure and function. Cell properties

MMG833.name: Microbial Genetics
MMG833.description: Gene structure and function. Genetic regulation at classical and molecular levels in prokaryotes and lower eukaryotes.
MMG833.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Colleges of Human Medicine, Osteopathic Medicine, Veterinary Medicine, Natural Science, and Agriculture and Natural Resources.

MMG835.name: Eukaryotic Molecular Genetics
MMG835.description: Gene structure and function in animals, plants, and fungi. Basic aspects of modern human genetics and the genetic basis for disease. Molecular genetic analyses. Eukaryotic modeling systems.
MMG835.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the colleges of Agriculture and Natural Resources, Engineering, Human Medicine, Natural Science, Osteopathic Medicine, and Veterinary Medicine.

MMG845.name: Multi-disciplinary Research Methods for the Study of Evolution
MMG845.description: Techniques for engaging in multi-disciplinary research collaborations, including biology, computer science, and engineering. Students engage in group projects to answer fundamental questions about the dynamics of actively evolving systems including both natural and computational. Multi-disciplinary teams will learn to overcome discipline-specific language and conceptual issues. Experimental design, statistical analysis, data visualization, and paper and grant writing for multi-disciplinary audiences.

MMG851.name: Immunology
MMG851.description: Functional aspects of immune responses; synthesis, structure, and function of effector molecules; cell-cell interactions; current advances and research techniques.
MMG851.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Colleges of Human Medicine, Osteopathic Medicine, Veterinary Medicine, Natural Science, and Agriculture and Natural Resources.

MMG855.name: Molecular Evolution: Principles and Techniques
MMG855.description: Current techniques used to characterize and compare genes and genomes. Genetic variation, assays of variation. Data analysis and computer use to conduct a phylogenetic analysis to compare organisms and infer relationships.

MMG861.name: Advanced Microbial Pathogenesis
MMG861.description: Molecular basis of microbial virulence. Virulence factors of microorganisms and the relationship of these factors to disease; host-pathogen interactions.

MMG890.name: Special Problems in Microbiology
MMG890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MMG890.restrictions: Open to master's students in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics.

MMG892.name: Seminar
MMG892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MMG892.description: Student review and presentation of selected topics in microbiology and public health.
MMG892.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or College of Engineering or College of Human Medicine or College of Natural Science or College of Osteopathic Medicine or College of Veterinary Medicine.

MMG899.name: Master's Thesis Research
MMG899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MMG899.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Microbiology and Molecular Genetics.

MMG991.name: Topics in Microbiology
MMG991.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
MMG991.description: Topics are selected from traditional subdisciplines such as bacteriology, virology, cell biology, and immunology or from transecting subdisciplines such as microbial genetics, physiology, molecular biology and ecology.

MMG999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research (Interim Change)
MMG999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
MMG999.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Genetics Major or in the Microbiology and Molecular Genetics Major.
